message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A vaccine that prevents meningococcal disease is a conjugated polysaccharide vaccine. It consists of a portion of the surface capsule of the meningococcus bacterium that is linked to a protein to enhance the immune response. It is not live, attenuated or killed, inactivated. Toxoid vaccines are used to prevent diseases caused by bacteria that produce toxins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meningococcal vaccines are typically of the conjugated polysaccharide type, which creates an immune response to certain strains of meningococcal bacteria. Live attenuated vaccines use weakened or modified forms of the live microbe, killed inactivated vaccines use inactivated or dead microbe, and toxoid vaccines use a toxin produced by the microbe. None of these options are typically used for meningococcal disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meningococcal vaccines are usually conjugated polysaccharide vaccines, which means they contain a portion of the bacteria’s outer coating attached to a protein to enhance immune response. Live, attenuated vaccines contain a weakened form of the virus, killed, inactivated vaccines contain a dead form of the virus, and toxoid vaccines contain a modified toxin produced by the bacteria.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website for help. The vaccine that prevents meningococcal disease is a conjugated polysaccharide vaccine, which is recommended for college students living in dormitories to prevent outbreaks of meningococcal disease. Live, attenuated vaccines contain weakened forms of the disease-causing virus, while killed, inactivated vaccines contain dead viruses. Toxoid vaccines contain inactivated toxins produced by the disease-causing bacteria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meningococcal vaccines are usually conjugated polysaccharide vaccines, which contain pieces of the bacteria’s outer coating that have been attached to a protein to enhance the body’s immune response. Killed, inactivated vaccines contain dead virus or bacteria, while live, attenuated vaccines contain weakened virus or bacteria. Toxoid vaccines contain inactivated bacterial toxins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question mentions that the vaccine is given to prevent meningococcal disease, which is caused by a bacterial infection. Among the options, only the conjugated polysaccharide vaccine is used to prevent bacterial infections such as meningococcal disease. Live, attenuated vaccines are used for viruses, killed, inactivated vaccines are used for bacteria and viruses, and toxoid vaccines are used for toxins produced by bacteria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Meningococcal vaccines are either conjugated polysaccharide or recombinant protein-based. Among the options, only conjugated polysaccharide is a type of meningococcal vaccine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vaccine that prevents meningococcal disease is a conjugated polysaccharide vaccine, which consists of fragments of the meningococcal bacteria attached to a protein to enhance the body's immune response. Live, attenuated vaccines contain weakened forms of the disease-causing organism, killed, inactivated vaccines contain non-viable or dead organisms, and toxoid vaccines contain modified toxins produced by the organism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vaccine that prevents meningococcal disease is a conjugated polysaccharide vaccine. It is recommended for college students living in dormitories as they are at higher risk for the disease. Live, attenuated vaccines use live viruses that have been weakened, while killed, inactivated vaccines use viruses that have been killed. Toxoid vaccines use weakened toxins produced by bacteria, and are used for diseases caused by toxins rather than the bacteria itself.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only conjugated polysaccharide vaccine is used to prevent meningococcal disease. Live attenuated vaccines contain a weakened form of the virus, killed inactivated vaccines contain dead viruses, and toxoid vaccines contain inactivated toxins.
